#Text=David Powel
#Text=David Powel ( 1549/52 – 1598 ) was a Welsh Church of England clergyman and historian who published the first printed history of Wales in 1584 .
#Text=Life
#Text=Powel was born in Denbighshire and commenced his studies at the University of Oxford when he was 16 , sometime between 1566 and 1568 .
#Text=Whilst his initial college membership is not known , it is known that he moved to Jesus College when it was founded in 1571 .
#Text=He obtained his B.A. degree on 3 March 1573 and is thought to have been the college 's first graduate . [ 1 ]
#Text=He obtained his M.A. on 6 July 1576 .
#Text=Before Powel graduated , he had been named as vicar of Ruabon , Denbighshire and rector of Llanfyllin , Montgomeryshire .
#Text=He became vicar of Meifod in place of his Llanfyllin position in 1579 , and was also the holder of two prebends at St Asaph Cathedral .
#Text=After further study , he obtained degrees of B. Th . on 19 February 1583 and D. Th . on 11 April 1583 .
#Text=He was then private chaplain to Sir Henry Sidney , president of the Council in the marches of Wales , from about 1584 to 1586 .
#Text=He died in 1598 in Ruabon , where he was buried . [ 1 ]
#Text=One of his sons was Gabriel Powell , also a clergyman , and a strident anti- Catholic . [ 2 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Powel made a significant contribution to developing and preserving Welsh culture and to the growth of Protestantism in Wales .
#Text=He was a supporter of William Morgan 's efforts to translate the Bible into Welsh .
#Text=He kept the Privy Council informed about illegal books circulating amongst Roman Catholics in Wales . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was a respected scholar and was associated with geographers such as John Dee and Richard Hakluyt .

#Text=In 1573 , Powel took over the task of preparing for publication an English translation ( by Humphrey Llwyd ) of some medieval Welsh chronicles , upon which John Dee had been working before leaving England .

#Text=Powel expanded Llwyd 's work in its scope and detail , with the help of Lord Burghley providing access to some further documents , making his own contributions clear by typographical distinctions .
#Text=The resulting publication in 1584 , The Historie of Cambria , now called Wales , was the first printed history of Wales . [ 1 ]
#Text=The work remained an important source for medieval Welsh history for several centuries thereafter .

#Text=It also popularised the legend that Prince Madoc had discovered America in about 1170 , a tale used to justify English encroachments on the territory of Spanish America ( for example in Hakluyt 's Discourse on Western Planting ) . [ 1 ]

#Text=Powel also published a volume with editions of Ponticus Virunnius 's Historia Britannica , and Gerald of Wales 's Itinerarium Cambriae ( ' Journey through Wales ' , 1191 ) and Descriptio Cambriae ( ' Description of Wales ' , 1194 ) , but omitted Gerald 's negative comments about the Welsh .
#Text=The volume was dedicated to Sidney .
#Text=He is also said ( by the later lexicographer John Davies ) to have worked on an unpublished Welsh dictionary . [ 1 ]
